awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  The role of male-male competition in driving weapon diversification and speciation
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. The research component of this fellowship investigates the evolution of exaggerated animal weapons. Examples of such weapons include the branching antlers of deer, the enlarged claws of crabs, and the elongated horns of beetles. At their extremes, these weapons can compose up to half of an individual's body mass (e.g., claws in fiddler crabs) and can be more than twice an individual's body length (e.g., front legs in harlequin beetles). Moreover, these weapons can dramatically differ in their size and shape among closely related species. The fellow will specifically investigate the factors that promote this weapon variation. Investigating the evolution of animal weapons can provide insights into: 1) arms-races between weapons and defensive structures, 2) the importance of plant diversity in driving animal diversity, and 3) other factors that promote new morphological structures. The broader impacts associated with this fellowship include undergraduate mentoring, enhancing and expanding the digitization of museum collections, and the production of scientific research videos for the public. 

The fellow will use data from museum specimens in combination with phylogenetic comparative methods to investigate the degree to which male-male competition promotes phenotypic diversification and speciation in leaf-footed bugs (Insecta: Hemiptera: Coreidae). Specifically, the fellow will test multiple weapon diversification hypotheses and determine the extent to which male-male competition influences speciation and net diversification. Because the role of male-male competition in diversification has been largely neglected, this research will help clarify whether selection via differential access to mates generally promotes phenotypic diversification and speciation or whether such patterns are specific to female choice. This research will also contribute to museum digitization efforts, mentoring of undergraduate researchers, and the fellow's professional development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Competition over access to mates has led to the evolution of elaborate weaponry in many animals. Some examples include the horns of rhinoceros beetles, the antlers of deer, and the enlarged claws of many crabs. These weapons can also dramatically differ in their size and shape among closely related species. For example, the antlers on a moose are different than those on a reindeer. This proposal investigated factors that promote weapon diversity and investigated whether such weaponry affected the rate at which lineages diversify. 

The PI and their colleagues investigated hypotheses for weapon diversification using both comparative analyses and behavioral experiments. A fundamental assumption about animal weapons is that their morphologies evolve to help individuals outcompete their rivals. Thus, a straightforward hypothesis is that weapon diversification is driven by selection for weapon modifications that provide an advantage in combat. The PI and their colleagues tested this hypothesis by quantifying weapon diversity and damage from male-male competition among 17 insect species that were closely related. They found that weapons with certain modifications inflict more damage. Moreover, through a series of behavioral experiments, the PI and their colleagues experimentally show that (1) damage acquired during combat is costly, and (2) that the accumulation of fighting-related damage has an important role in determining who will ultimately win a given fight. Collectively, these results support the hypothesis that weapon performance can drive weapon evolution and may help explain how animal weapons have evolved into the diversity of forms seen today.

The PI and their colleagues also investigated the degree to which male-male competition influences speciation using a phylogenetic comparative approach. They specifically investigated whether weaponry associated with male-male competition promoted speciation and diversification in three insect groups. They found no evidence that weapon-bearing lineages had higher rates of speciation than their weaponless relatives. Thus, their results suggest that male-male competition may not have strong, general effects on speciation in insects, a group encompassing more than half of all described species. 

With regards to broader impacts, the PI and their colleagues (1) communicated their finding to the public, (2) mentored a student in STEM, (3) digitized museum specimens, and (4) engaged in career development. Dissemination of the findings to the public was through twitter, news interviews, and podcasts. More than 116,000 people saw tweets relevant to this proposal. Moreover, the PI discussed this work with local news organizations and national podcasts for further dissemination. Aspects of this proposal also included the mentorship of an undergraduate researcher and digitization of museum specimens. Finally, the PI developed a comparative analysis skill set that will help them address fundamental questions in evolutionary biology throughout their scientific career.
